Literature Humanities through the years: Tracking Black authors in the Columbia Core

Black authors

Non-Black authors

Number of books

0

5

10

15

20

25

30

35

Toni Morrison’s “Song of Solomon” becomes the first text by a Black author to be added to the Literature Humanities syllabus.

2015

2016

2017

The Committee on the Core adds Suzan-Lori Parks’ “Father Comes Home from the Wars” to the syllabus in a newly created, annually rotating contemporary text slot. The slot is eventually canceled due to the pandemic.

2018

2019

The Committee on the Core adds three works by Black authors: Aime Cesaire’s “Notebook of a Return to the Native Land,” Machado de Assis’ “The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas,” and Claudia Rankine’s “Citizen.”

 

“Father Comes Home from the Wars” is codified into the syllabus.

 

2020

2021

2022

“Notebook of a Return to the Native Land” is removed.

 

2023

“Father Comes Home from the Wars” and “The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas” are removed, leaving two works by Black authors on the syllabus: “Song of Solomon” and “Citizen.”

2024

2025

Source: Columbia Core Curriculum

Graphic by Wilson Zhen

2018

“Father Comes Home from the Wars” and “The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas” are removed, leaving two works by Black authors on the syllabus: “Song of Solomon” and “Citizen.”
